w:r.w:t: The student will be introduced to the different shapes in this lesson. Knowing different shapes help with describing different things and building an English vocabulary. The student will learn how to pronounce and spell different shapes. The student will l
earn how to describe different objects and things with different shapes using words they learned already in previous lessons. The student will respond in complete sentences.
At completion of this lesson, student will be able to:
Recognize, spell, and pronounce the words for shapes.
Recognize the concept of size: big, small, bigger, smaller
Spell and pronounce commonly associated words.
circle, square, rectangle, diamond, triangle, shape
This slide will always be the
-branded opener slide that the teacher will display as the student enters the classroom.
Greet your student and introduce the lesson concept: Today, we are going to be learning about the different shapes
Identify as many of the shapes as possible
on the screen for student. Have the student repeat it and write it out on a separate piece of paper.

. Have student repeat and write out the phrase on the screen or on a separate piece of paper.
Direct student to circle the triangle.
Visual cue: As student says the phrase, they can complete actions for key words. For example, when they get to “triangle”
they can draw the shape of a triangle. When they get to “small” they can pinch together two fingers.
. Have student repeat and write out the phrase on the screen or on a separate piece of paper.
Direct student to circle the circle.
Visual cue: As student says the phrase, they can complete actions for key words. F
or example, when they get to “circle” they can draw the shape of a circle. When they get to “big” they can stretch their arms as far out as they can reach.
square is smaller than the rectangle
Do the actions for key words in the phrase (“square”; “smaller” “rectangle”)
square is smaller than the rectangle.
Have student repeat and write out t
he phrase on the screen or on a separate piece of paper.
Direct student to circle the square.
Visual cue: As student says the phrase, they can complete actions for key words. For example, when they get to “square” they can draw the shape of a square. When
they get to “rectangle” they can draw its shape. When they get to “smaller” they can pinch their fingers together.
diamond is bigger than the triangle
Do the actions for key words in the sentence (“diamond”, “bigger
diamond is bigger than the triangle.
Have student repeat and write out the phrase on the screen or on a separate piece of paper.
Direct student to circle the diamond.
Visual cue: As student says the phrase, they can complete actions for key words. For example, when they get to “diamond” the
y can draw the shape of a diamond. When they get to “triangle” they can draw its shape. When they get to “bigger” they can spread their hands out to as far as they can reach.
Match the sight word to the picture
Complete the sentence frame: This is a circle.

Circle the picture of the circle. Ask student to identify the correct shape. The student can use these actions instead of speaking their answer: one finger (circle), two fingers (triangle), three fingers (square).

The circle is bigger than the diamond
Ask student to circle and say which shape is bigger. Emphasize to the student that the answer should be in a complete sentence.
Give student the following sentence frame to use for their answer:
The ___________(circle) is bigger than the diamond.
As an extension, ask student to indicate which shape is smaller
Ask student to circle and say which shape is smaller. Emphasize to the student that the answer should be in a complete sentence.
Give student the following sentence frame to use
As an extension, ask student to indicate which shape is
Circle the picture of the clock. Ask student to answer the question in a complete sentence.

Freeform “Show and Tell” Conversation Activity Slide Number 21
Student should have a blank slide to draw a picture of different objects that have different shapes.
Teacher will prompt student to draw a picture to represent the different shapes through pictures. One prompt at a time.
Teacher will write words from the lesson (
shape, circle, square, rectangle, diamond, triangle)
l Vocabulary Builder Activity Slide Number 22
Student will read and spell their new words (
shape, circle, square, rectangle, diamond, triangle).
Teacher will give feedback on the spelling and pronunciation of the new words.
